subject: libvirt: Kill rsync/scp processes before deleting instance
commit_message:
libvirt: Kill rsync/scp processes before deleting instance

In the resize operation, during copying files from source to
destination compute node scp/rsync processes are not aborted after
the instance is deleted because linux kernel doesn't delete instance
files physically until all processes using the file handle is closed
completely. Hence rsync/scp process keeps on running until it
transfers 100% of file data.

Added new module instancejobtracker to libvirt driver which will add,
remove or terminate the processes running against particular instances.
Added callback methods to execute call which will store the pid of
scp/rsync process in cache as a key: value pair and to remove the
pid from the cache after process completion. Process id will be used to
kill the process if it is running while deleting the instance. Instance
uuid is used as a key in the cache and pid will be the value.

SecurityImpact

Closes-bug: #1387543
Change-Id: Ie03acc00a7c904aec13c90ae6a53938d08e5e0c9

subject: Improve the guestagent configuration manager
commit_message:
Improve the guestagent configuration manager

The current version of the configuration manager lacks
certain features that turn out to be required by some of the
ongoing projects.

 - The current implementation allows the caller to
   apply 'system' configuration overrides, but does not provide
   an easy way for removing them.
 - The current implementation of the RollingOverrideStrategy
   does not allow for an easy update of an existing configuration
   override via the guestagent API.
 - The manager duplicates some checks already made at a higher level
   (maximum number of configuration groups applied to an instance etc.)
   This duplication is not neccessary and more importantly may
   put the instance in a state difficult to recover from without
   direct access to the guestagent FS
   (e.g. configuration group gets detached in the Trove database, but
   not on the FS).

Proposed change:

 - Rework and simplify the override strategy implementation.
 - Remove the duplicate checks - the configuration manager leaves
   the validation on the API and does not impose any limits on the number
   of attached groups itself.
 - Allow the caller to remove 'system' overrides.
 - Replace the RollingOverrideStrategy with OneFileOverrideStrategy which
   uses the Import strategy to keep the overrides internally.
   When an override is applied or removed a new configuration file is
   generated by applying all changes on a saved-off base revision.
   This implementation based on the ImportOverrideStrategy allows
   great simplification of the code and provides an easy way to
   re-apply (edit) and remove existing overrides.

Closes-Bug: 1471905
Change-Id: Icfd58deeaf6bb368912dffe69566034a65f5854e

commit_message:
Update dhcp agent cache for network:dhcp ports

When a network with a dhcp_enabled subnet is scheduled on a dhcp
agent, dhcp driver creates the network:dhcp port for the subnet.
However, the port info is not updated in dhcp agents internal cache.
Subsequently if the user deletes the network:dhcp port, the port is
properly deleted on the server side (i.e., in the database) and when
the port_delete_end notification is sent to the dhcp agent, it simply
ignores it as the port entry would be missing in the cache. This patch
fixes this issue by updating the dhcp agents cache when dhcp driver
creates the network:dhcp port for the subnets.

subject: Introduce usage data tracking for Neutron
commit_message:
Introduce usage data tracking for Neutron

This patch introduces application logic support for tracking
Neutron resource usage data, thus introducing a different
way of enforcing quota limits, which now relies on records
tracking resource usage for each tenant.

When these records go "out-of-sync" with actual resource usage,
the quota usage table entry is marked "dirty".
And it will be resynchronized the next time a resource count is
requested. Changes in resource utilization are detected using
SQLAlchemy events.

This patch however does not automatically enable resource usage
tracking for any plugin. Plugins must explicitly declare for which
resources they wish to enable tracking. To this aim, this patch
provides the @tracked_resources decorator.

As some operators might wish to not use resource usage tracking, this
patch adds the track_quota_usage configuration option. If set to
False, DB-level usage tracking will not be performed, and
resources will be counted as before, ie: invoking a plugin method.

Usage tracking is performed using a new resource type,
TrackedResource, which can work side by side with CountableResource,
the one Neutron used so far. To this aim a ResourceRegistry class
has been introduced for registering and managing resources. Most
of the resource management code previously embedded in the
QuotaEngine class is being moved to ResourceRegistry as a part of
this patch.

Partially implements blueprint better-quota

subject: gnocchi: concurrently post resource/measures
commit_message:
gnocchi: concurrently post resource/measures

Without the batch dispatch, oslo.messaging calls 64 (rpc_thread_pool_size)
times record_metering_data, each message contains ~ 1 sample,
64 concurrently HTTP requests are done to gnocchi with 1 sample each.

But with the batch, this 64 record_metering_data are merged into one
record_metering_data call of the gnocchi dispatch with 64 samples
into the payload (more if the rpc_thread_pool_size and the batch
size are increased).

This change allows in this case to parallize the handling of this
samples by creating a threadpool. Each task done in the
thread corresponds to the job to for one resource.

subject: Adds batch dispatcher
commit_message:
Adds batch dispatcher

This adds a batch dispatcher.

It waits for N seconds (life) or for N messages (size) in the
samples/events queue. And then do one call to others dispatchers
with all samples/events merged.

Example of configuration use this dispatcher:

  [DEFAULT]
  rpc_thread_pool_size = 512
  dispatcher = batch

  [dispatcher_batch]
  size = 512
  dispatcher = gnocchi

oslo.messaging threads are hold until the samples/events is
really dispatched to:

* propagate exception correctly to the initial oslo.messaging thread.
* requeue/ack messages correctly.
* unack messages if collector crash or (unexpectedly) stopped.

subject: Fix saving tz aware datetimes in Versioned Objects
commit_message:
Fix saving tz aware datetimes in Versioned Objects

Currently we cannot save date fields in Versioned Objects because they
are timezone aware and our database is not.

If we look at our objects definition, we are not giving any value to
tzinfo_aware argument, so it takes DateTime default value (True).

In our sqlalchemy model definitions we are defining our datetime fields
as Column(DateTime) which will take sqlalchemy default: class
sqlalchemy.types.DateTime(timezone=False)

In most cases we are accessing those fields directly through the DB
methods, so we don't see the problem, but if we were to modify any of
those fields using versioned object, for example scheduled_at, and then
save the object we'll get an exception:

 File ".../sqlalchemy/sql/type_api.py", line 278, in compare_values
 return x == y
 TypeError: can't compare offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes

Because we are trying to save a timezone aware date to a timezone
unaware DB field.

Following Dan's advice we create a specific cinder_obj_get_changes,
instead of overwriting obj_get_changes, that returns all datefields as
timezone naive UTC datetimes ready for saving.

Change-Id: Ie7b0249e3f6850e7c70d23fc53cfaf27fe04afbb
Closes-Bug: #1469120

commit_message:
[WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: adding agent and scheduling

Dynamic routing needs a new agent that will host the BGP speaker driver
and will do the actual communication between BGP peers.

This agent will take information from a single Routing Instance entity,
that has all the information that the agent needs to do the routing
exchange: peers and routes. In this approach, an agent can only host one
Routing Instance to avoid conflicts.

This commit intruduces a dummy agent that auto-registers to Neutron API
and send keep-alive messages.

A binding between the agent and the routing instance is mandatory in the
database and also the api endpoints to let the user
associate/disassociate a routing instante to an agent.

There is also an autoscheduling feature that will assign a routing
instance to the first agent that asks for synchronization. Default
scheduler class will only assign non-assigned routing instances to

subject: Update hacking to 0.10.0
commit_message:
Update hacking to 0.10.0

Replace the whitelist of flake8 checks (select) with a blacklist
(ignore).  It makes possible to disable a single check, which was not
possible before. This new approach permits to enable new tests more
easily and see which checks are currently disabled.

Only new checks are disabled, this change doesn't run less checks than
before. Currently, many checks are disabled, but following changes will
fix these new warnings.

When the "select" option of flake8 is used in tox.ini, the "ignore"
option is ignored. It is not possible to use "select" and "ignore"
options at the same time. See the code in pep8 (flake8 is based on
pep8):

https://github.com/PyCQA/pep8/blob/d48eef071003952ed0f98445dc3dc6bc29618f9c/pep8.py#L1808

The purpose of flake8 is to enhance the coding style, but also to help
to detect common bugs. Blacklisting checks permits to detect new bugs
when upgrading the tools. For example, new checks were recently added to
help porting code to Python 3.

This change permits to use pbr 1.0 and newer which is required to
support Python 3. Previously, hacking 0.8.1 was used, but hacking 0.8 is
incompatible with pbr 1.0 and newer (hacking 0.8 requires pbr<1.0).

pbr 1.0 is required to use environment markers on requirements to
install dnspython on Python 2 and dnspython3 on Python 3.

distributed coordinated notifications

this patch enables a queue per pipeline per agent. each agent can
send data to pipeline queue set of any agent but only listens to it's
own pipeline queue. when receiving a notification, the agent will:
1. build datapoint
2. calculate hash key based on (hardcoded) attribute and mod hash
   by number of active agents
3. sends the data to single agents pipeline queue set.

   pipeline queue.
2a. agent2 process sample1
3. hash(sample2) % 2 (num agents) == agent1 sends sample to agent1

subject: [WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: adding agent and scheduling
commit_message:
[WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: adding agent and scheduling

Dynamic routing needs a new agent that will host the BGP speaker driver
and will do the actual communication between BGP peers.
This agent will take information from a single BGP speaker entity,
that has all the information that the agent needs to do the routing
exchange: peers and routes. In this approach, an agent can only host one
BGP speaker to avoid conflicts.
This commit intruduces a dummy agent that auto-registers to Neutron API
and send keep-alive messages.

A binding between the agent and the BGP speaker is mandatory in the
database and also the api endpoints to let the user
associate/disassociate a BGP speaker to an agent.
There is also an autoscheduling feature that will assign a BGP speaker
to the first agent that asks for synchronization. Default
scheduler class will only assign non-assigned BGP speakers to
agents.

HA feature (two agents hosting the same routing instance) has to be done manually.

Outstanding Items:
- Unit and API testcases
- RpcCallback implementation
